awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Maskless Aligner
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a Heidelberg Maskless Aligner photolithography tool (MLA150) to enhance micro/nanofabrication initiatives at the University of Maryland College Park (UMD) and its surrounding institutions. Photolithography – a process of defining micrometer-scale patterns by using ultraviolet light to selectively expose mask patterns in a coating of light-sensitive polymer – is a ubiquitous process which underlies modern electronic devices from microcontrollers and processor chips to novel battery designs, biomedical devices, and even developing quantum-computer technologies. The MLA150 instrument allows researchers to laser-print lithography patterns without the need for mask, greatly reducing the expense and cost of improving and developing new device designs. The instrument supports various research projects in materials science, nanoscience, energy science, and quantum science and students training at UMD. 

The proposed MLA150 system is an essential yet powerful tool to promote a wide range of both fundamental and applied science studies, including but not limited to realization of compact battery cells, improved micro-electron-mechanical devices, higher-quality quantum sensors, and novel superconducting-circuit devices. The instrument eliminates delays associated with mask ordering, validation, printing, and shipping, allowing researchers at UMD to move from design to device in a less than one day. The resulting rapid fabrication cycle times greatly expands the range of device geometries that can be explored, promote the exploration of new design concepts that would otherwise be impractical to implement, and improve the overall agility of microsystems and nanosystems research at UMD. Furthermore, the tool complements to the existing mask aligners as it can be used to produce permanent masks for finalized designs, which can then be made with higher through-put using conventional mask aligners, turning mask production from a slow expensive process to a rapid and versatile in-house one.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supported the acquisition of a Heidelberg Maskless Aligner photolithography tool (MLA150) to enhance micro/nanofabrication efforts at the University of Maryland College Park and its surrounding institutions. Photolithography – a process of defining micrometer-scale patterns by using ultra-violet light to selectively expose mask patterns in a coating of light-sensitive polymer– is a ubiquitous process which underlies modern electronic devices from microcontrollers and processor chips to novel battery designs, biomedical devices, and even developing quantum-computer technologies. The MLA150 instrument now allows researchers to laser print lithography patterns without the need for mask, greatly reducing the expense and cost of improving and developing new device designs. The instrument supports various research projects in materials science, nanoscience, energy science, and quantum science and students training at the University of Maryland.

The instrument already has 30+ fully trained users, even though it has only been available for training for less than a year. These students are now able learn state-of-the-art high throughput lithography design and will become lithography designers and developers, rather than just basic users.

 

The tool allows users to optimize and improve photolithography processes at as scale never before possible and is currently being harnessed for advancement in a large number of fields. It sees both graduate and postdoctoral users spanning both the natural sciences and engineering, who hail from departments as widely varied as physics, electrical engineering, materials science, chemistry, and mechanical engineering. The tool also has external commercial users and external academic users for nearby universities.

 

The associated figure shows an example of a device from a project which was transformed by the acquisition of the maskless aligner. Creation of this superconducting microwave resonator network with built-in transmon qubits was made possible thanks to the high-resolution and rapid iteration time provided by the Heidelberg MLA150 Maskless Aligner.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2023
Modified by: Alicia J Kollar

Image
  • Superconducting microwave device made possible by the maskless aligner purchased through this award. a) Device photo. b) CAD Design. c) Graph connectivity of the device. d) Closeup of the CAD for the superconducting qubits in the device (purple highlights in b).
    Alicia Koll�r, Maya Amouzegar
    Copyrighted
    Alicia J Kollar
    Device Design Made Possible by the Maskless Aligner
